facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1961 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Writ No. 86 of 1960.

facts.text: The respondent obtained a mining lease for extracting sandstone from mines in certain area from the Government of Rajasthan in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent obtained the mining lease for extracting sand- stone from the mines in certain area from the Government of Rajastha

facts.text: The mining lease was granted as a result of auction.

issues.text: the question of the applicability of the provisions of Chapter IV and thereby of r. 30 of the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955, hereinafter called the rules, to the grants of mining leases under the provisions of Chapter V of the rules.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate granted by the Rajasthan High Court, raises the question of the applicability of the provisions of Chapter IV and thereby of r. 30 of the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955,

issues.text: whether the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules govern the grant of mining leases by auction under the provisions of Chapter V of the rules

anchor.surface_text: Two questions are raised for the appellant in this Court. The first is that the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules do not govern the grant of mining leases by auction under the provisions of Chapter V of the rules.

issues.text: whether the proviso to r. 30 gives discretion to the State Government to extend the period of the lease for any period not exceeding 5 years or whether it is mandatory that the State Government must extend the lease by a period of 5 years

anchor.surface_text: The other is that the proviso to r. 30 gives discretion to the State Government to extend the period of the lease for any period not exceeding 5 years that it is not mandatory that the State Government must extend the lease by a period of 5 years as held by the High Court.

issues.text: whether the shorter period of the lease in favour of the respondent must be deemed to have been at his request

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules were applicable as far as possible to the grant of mining leases by auction under Chapter V. that though the State Government had to give a lease for 5 years in view of r. 30, yet the shorter period of the lease in favour of the respondent must, in the circumstances, be deemed to have been at his request

holdings.text: The provisions of Chapter IV of the rules apply to mining leases granted under Chapter V insofar as they are applicable.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the contention that the rules under Chapter IV do not apply to mining leases granted under Chapter V is not sound and that the High Court rightly held that they do apply so far as applicable to mining leases granted under Chapter V.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: Chapter IV heading general; many rules (19,26,27,29,31,32) essential and incorporated by reference (r.41); no contrary provision in Ch V; policy requires restrictions etc. apply universally.

holdings.text: Rule 30 applies to mining leases granted under Chapter V.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 30 deals with the period of lease. This rule will apply to leases granted under Chapter V both because the rules under Chapter IV apply to such leases and because there is no corresponding rule in Chapter V.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ch IV applies generally; no specific rule in Ch V for lease period; essential term must be governed.

holdings.text: Under r.30, a mining lease must be granted for 5 years unless the applicant desires a shorter period; 'may' means 'shall' and is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The word may in the main provision of the rule must mean shall and make the provision mandatory. This is obvious from the last portion of the provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'may' construed as mandatory to avoid redundancy (Govt could shorten anyway); proviso structure requires full 5 years for options.

holdings.text: The proviso to r.30 requires mandatory extension for 5 years if lessee desires; 'may' means 'shall'; first extension full 5 years to enable second option and 3-year investment guarantee.

anchor.surface_text: The word may in the proviso in regard to the extension of the period by Government should also be construed as shall so as to make it incumbent on Government to extend the period of the lease if the lessee desires extension.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive/harmonious: Otherwise redundant; fits structure with options and guarantee within 3 years; lessee option drives 'may'.

holdings.text: The respondent's bidding and acceptance of the shorter lease period (to July 31, 1959) amounts to desiring a shorter period under r.30.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of opinion that the High Court is right in holding that the respondents taking the lease for a period upto July 31, 1959 must amount to his expressing a desire for having a lease for that period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application to facts: Auction bid for specific short period expresses desire; otherwise would not have bid.

holdings.text: High Court direction for 5-year renewal with option for further 5 years not in excess of prayer; competent under r.30 proviso.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prayer for renewal under r.30 implicitly includes proviso terms (option integral); court can mould relief accordingly.

holdings.text: High Court correctly held on applicability of Ch IV/r.30 and mandatory nature; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the High Court has come to a right conclusion on these two points.
